_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Stationary Source: Rhodia, Inc., 399 Sims Chapel Road, Spartanburg, SC 29306-6123

Regulated substances handled: Ethylene oxide, propylene oxide, and, allyl alcohol

Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies: The facilty accidental
release prevention policy can be summarized as follows: All facility personel will be
trained in and expected to comply with the site-specific policies pertaining to accidental
release prevention. Primary accidental release prevention policy documents are found in:
  Engineering & Maintenance Procedures
  Environmental (WWTP) Operating Procedures
  Production Operating Procedures
  Site-wide Risk Management Procedures

Emergency response policies: The facility emergency response policy can be summarized
as follows: All facility personnel will be trained in and expected to comply with the site
specific policies pertaining to emergency response. Primary emergency response policy
documents are found in:
  Risk Management Procedure RM007
  Engineering & Maintenance Procedures
  Environmental (WWTP) Operating Procedures
  Production Operating Procedures
  Site-wide Risk Management Procedures

Worst Case Release Scenario: Involves a release of ethylene oxide from a railcar on our
siding. This scenario assumes that the entire contents of a railcar (180,000 lbs) would be
released within a ten minute time period. This is modeled to a concentration of 50 parts
per million (ERPG-2) of ethylene oxide into the air, which has a theoretical impact zone of
4.08 miles. This scenario is required to assume highly improbable circumstances including
that the event could occur, to begin with, and that all safety pevention and emergency
response measures all fail at the same time.

Alternate release scenarios include administrative controls and mitigation measures. The
three alternate release scenarios included in the RMP are for each of the three regulated
toxic chemicals handled on site above the TQ's (allyl alcohol, ethylene oxide, and, p

ropylene
oxide). Administrative controls to limit potential offsite impacts include chain-of-command
management with specific overlapping staff assignments for release prevention, emergency
response, etc.; 24 hours a day, seven days per week facility staffing; active fire watch
during holiday shutdown periods; active embership in and coordination with the Spartanburg
County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC); and, active membership in and coordination
with the Arkwright Voluntary Fire Department (AVFD). Mitigation measures to limit potential
offsite impact include state-of-the-art leak detection and control systems; railcar unloading
station equipped with a three car emergency deluge system; dedicaed diesel powered
emergency fire water supply system; and, almost 40 remote emergency alarms throughout
the facility. The alternative release scenario for the site with the greatest potential offsite
impact involves a release of 175,000 pounds of liquid ethylene oxide due to the complete
failure of the primary pressure relief valve on the EO storage tank. This release scenario
assumes it would take a more reasonable period of time (at least 36 minutes) to completely
empty the vessel. When modeled to a final dispersal concentration of 50 parts per million
of ethylene oxide, ERPG-2 conditions, the effects of this scenario reach a distance of
less than half a mile (0.48 miles). The alternate relase scenarios modeled for allyl alchol
(transfer hose failure resulting in 12,995 pounds released) and propylene oxide (relief
valve failure and release of 62,820 pounds) have a potential offsite impacts of areas smaller
than the model for ethylene oxide. Specifically, the the propylene oxide and allyl alcohol
alternate release scenarios would impact areas approximately 370 feet and 740 feet from
the spill, respectively.

General accidental release prevention program: The site's Risk Management Procedure
RM007, Emergency Response, addresses these issues.

Chemical specific preve

ntion steps: These issues are already addressed above with
respect to accidental release prevention policies, and emergency response policies.

Five year accident history: None to report.

Emergency respopnse program: These issues are already addressed above under
the Emergency Respons Policy topic.

Planned changes to impove safety: Among other things, periodic review and implementation,
as appropriate, of plant process safety plans, and resolution of periodic process hazard
analysis recommendations.

Added two processes: temporary storage of one Ethylene Oxide railcar, and, temporary storage of one Propylene Oxide railcar. These processes are not aggregated for worst-case and alternatate worst-case scenarios.
